Hirono, Hawaii Congressional Delegation Introduce Legislation to Address Working Conditions in Hawaii’s Longline Fishing Fleet   Sustainable Fishing Workforce Protection Act Would Provide Nonimmigrant Work Visas, Promotes Transparency in Compensation and Workplace Safety, Clarifies Federal Enforcement & Oversight   WASHINGTON, D.C.- Senator Mazie K. Hirono and the Hawaii Congressional Delegation introduced the Sustainable Fishing Workforce Protection Act, legislation that would address concerns about the status of foreign workers in Hawaii’s longline fishing fleet.   “This bill provides necessary protections for foreign fishermen and ensures the continued viability of Hawaii’s longline fishing fleet, which is important to our culture,” said Senator Hirono. “Throughout this process, I have worked with a range of stakeholders and will continue to do so as we work to pass this legislation.”   “The Sustainable Fishing Workforce Protection Act addresses longstanding allegations in the Hawaii fishing industry regarding the treatment of foreign workers on longline commercial fishing vessels homeported in Hawaii,” said Representative Colleen Hanabusa.  “I am optimistic this legislative framework will allow Congress to better define the employer-employee relationship between boat owners and foreign fisherman such that each side understands their rights and obligations.  I look forward to working with the rest of the Hawaii delegation and my colleagues in the House as we move this bill forward into law.”    “This legislation is about providing safety, protecting human rights, and restoring dignity to the foreign crewmen working in Hawaii’s fishing fleet,” said Senator Brian Schatz. “I will continue to work with our congressional delegation to pass this bill and improve the working conditions on all our vessels.”   “For years, disjointed laws have left foreign fishermen working off our shores without federal protections or status, and at risk for inhumane conditions and human rights abuses,” said Representative Tulsi Gabbard. “This legislation will increase employer accountability, strengthen federal oversight, and improve working conditions for these workers that contribute to our local economy.”      Senator Hirono introduced the bill, S. 2071, in the Senate with Senator Schatz. Representative Hanabusa introduced the companion legislation, H.R. 4224, in the House with Representative Gabbard.   The Sustainable Fishing Workforce Protection Act would:   Provide foreign fishermen in the Hawaii fleet with visas that will allow them to transit to and from and work legally in the U.S.   Establish a baseline of responsibilities for employers by outlining the components of labor agreements that they and the foreign workers must agree to governing wages and other compensation; requiring that the terms of those agreements be enforceable in U.S. court or by voluntary arbitration; and requiring that signed copies of the agreements be kept on file at relevant federal and state agencies.   Clarify oversight responsibilities of federal agencies with respect to health and safety issues for the Hawaii fishing fleet.   ###

November 8, 2017 For Immediate Release  Congresswoman Hanabusa Introduces Bipartisan Legislation to Honor Those Who Served in the Pacific Theater During World War II   Washington, D.C. – Today, Congresswoman Hanabusa, joined by Congressman Rob Bishop (R-UT), Chairman of the House Committee on Natural Resources, introduced the “Admiral Lloyd R. ‘Joe’ Vasey Pacific War Commemorative Display Establishment Act.”  This bill would establish a memorial at Pearl Harbor to honor the U.S. service members who served in the Pacific Theater during World War II, also known as the Pacific War.    From 1941 through 1945, U.S. service members fought alongside allied service members on land, in the air, and at sea throughout the Pacific Theater.  Over 150,000 U.S. and allied lives were lost in the Pacific War.  “This memorial will honor those who valiantly served our country in the Pacific Theater, share their history with future generations and provide a place for loved ones to mourn those they lost in the war” said Congresswoman Hanabusa.  “I can think of no better place for a Pacific War memorial than at Pearl Harbor, where the USS Arizona commemorates the entry of the United States into World War II and the USS Missouri memorializes the site where World War II formally ended.  Admiral Joe Vasey, who served in the Pacific War and who turned 100 years old earlier this year, deserves the credit for this memorial.  Admiral Vasey dedicated his life to promoting peace throughout the Pacific and I am committed to honoring him and his vision for this memorial.  Finally, I thank Congressman Bishop, who chairs the House Committee on Natural Resources and also serves on Armed Services.  Congressman Bishop understands the debt of gratitude and recognition we owe our veterans.  The Valor of the Pacific falls under the jurisdiction of the Committee on Natural Resources and I look forward to working with Chairman Bishop on the passage of this important bill.”  “This legislation will memorialize the brave service members who defended our country in the Pacific Theater,” said Congressman Bishop.  “I commend Rep. Hanabusa for her commitment to honoring and remembering our nation’s World War II veterans for generations to come.”  “This memorial to American and Allied veterans and the fallen of World War II Pacific Theater battles is essential to remember and honor their sacrifices.  I thank Congresswoman Hanabusa for her efforts to make this memorial a reality,” said Alma Grocki, Rear Admiral, U.S. Navy (Ret), Board Member, Pacific Historic Parks.  Admiral Lloyd R. ‘Joe’ Vasey served aboard the USS Gunnel in the Pacific during World War II, under John S. McCain, Jr., father of U.S. Senator John McCain, and has advocated for the establishment of this memorial.  Admiral Vasey founded the Pacific Forum CSIS (Center for Strategic and International Studies), a nonprofit, private, foreign policy research instituted focused on the Asia-Pacific.   His military service includes: chief of strategic plans and policies at U.S. Pacific Command Headquarters, secretary to the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff; deputy director of the U.S. National Military Command Center in the Pentagon; and chief of staff for Commander U.S. 7th Fleet.  Admiral Vasey turned 100 years old on January 31, 2017.    ####

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has addressed the effect of a GOP Tax Plan that raises the deficit by an estimated $1.5 trillion over the 2018-2027 period.  According to the CBO, the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 (PAYGO) requires that new legislation enacted during a term of Congress not collectively increase estimated deficits.  The OMB is required to keep 5 and 10 year scorecards and if a scorecard indicates an increase in the deficit, OMB is required to order a sequestration to eliminate the overage.  Since the GOP Tax Bill would increase the deficit by $1.5 trillion over a 10-year window, unless there is legislation offsetting the increase, Congress would be required to reduce spending by $136 billion in 2018 alone (there is a positive balance of $14 billion in 2018), with subsequent reductions calculated in each calendar year between 2019 and 2027.  While Medicare can only be reduced 4 percentage points (~$25B/year), $111 billion would have to come from other mandatory accounts.  Some large accounts, like Social Security, are exempt, making it very difficult to implement the full extent of the PAYGO law.  Bottomline, if the GOP Tax Plan passes, there will be required cuts to other mandatory programs between 2018 and 2027 absent offsetting legislation.

Here are the facts on why my Democratic colleagues and I oppose Mick Mulvaney as Acting Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB).  1. Instead, Congress provided specific language providing the "Deputy Director" would be acting in the event the Director was absent.  4.     When Mulvaney was a member of Congress and on the House Financial Services Committee, he called the CFPB a "joke."  He was also the original cosponsor of a bill designed to eliminate the CFPB.  5.     President Trump appointing Mulvaney as the acting Director of the CFPB is contrary to Congressional intent and compromises the independence of the consumer protection agency.

Here's another GOP bill with a clever name:  H.R. 4182, the "Ensuring a Qualified Civil Service Act of 2017 (EQUALS Act)."  This bill extends the probationary period from one (1) year to two (2) years for federal employees in the competitive service and the Senior Executive Service.    During the probationary period, federal employees are at-will employees with essentially no due-process or appeal rights.  After the probationary period, due process protections ensure the integrity of the federal civil service by preventing its politicization.  Without any indication federal agencies desired an additional year of probation, the GOP proposes to increase the probationary period to 2 years.  To make matters worse, under this bill, the 2-year probationary period does not necessarily begin at the time a federal worker is hired.  Instead, the probationary period would end on the date that is 2 years after the date on which required formal training is completed or a license is required and obtained.  For those federal workers that need a license or go through a formal training program, the probationary period is actually longer and, perhaps, much longer than 2 years.  After the current 1 year probation period, federal employers may still dismiss poor performers through a due process that includes notice, an opportunity to respond and appeal rights.  So why the need to increase the probationary period without due process rights to 2 years?

NOTICE OF PROPOSED RULEMAKING RE: EMPLOYEE TIPS The Department of Labor (Department) is proposing to rescind portions of its tip regulations issued pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act that impose restrictions on employers that pay a direct cash wage of at least the full federal minimum wage and do not seek to use a portion of tips as a credit toward their minimum wage obligations. This Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) seeks the views of the public on the Department's proposed rescission of those portions of the regulations. Essentially, the proposed rule rescinds parts of the Department's 2011 Tip Regulations that clarify tips are the property of an employee, regardless of whether an employer takes a tip credit against its obligation to pay the minimum wage or pays the tipped worker the full minimum wage. The proposed rule reverses the Department's position of more than 40 years and could impact up to 1.3 million tipped workers. The proposed rule means employers could be allowed to pocket workers' tips as long as the employer pays the worker a cash wage of at least the federal minimum wage of $7.25.

We were honored to participate in the Chaplain Memorial Dedication at The National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific this morning. The memorial honors more than 9,000 Chaplains who looked after our soldiers during World War II, with most of them serving in the Pacific. The U.S. Army Chaplain School opened in March, 1942 at Fort Benjamin Harrison, Indiana before later moving to Fort Devens, Massachusetts. Every U.S. soldier deployed in the Pacific during WWII was given a pocket bible, and their Chaplains tended to men from every major denomination and as many as 50 different religious groups. The Chaplains also trained to fight and many of them lost their lives in combat. Mahalo, to these brave soldiers for keeping the Faith while helping to defend our country.
